text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today 
is the day I am finally finally putting up

a instant pot recipe which many many many of you 
have requested over the years so for those of you

who don't know what an instant pot is it's it's 
this thing and it's become a bit of a sensation

in North America shall we say but it's basically 
a pressure cooker an electric pressure cooker it

does a bunch of other things it's a slow cooker 
and a few things but most people get it for its

pressure cooking ability so today I'm gonna 
share with you a massaman curry recipe which I

have modified to work with the instant pot but 
really the takeaway that I want you to have by

the end of this video is how do you take sort of 
any curry recipe and modify it so that you can

use it with your instant pot so this is a recipe 
that would normally take me like three hours and

we can actually do it in about 40 45 minutes which 
is pretty cool maybe an hour Oh No yeah we'll talk

about that alright let's get started let's talk 
curry paste first you can certainly buy massaman

curry paste which is a little harder to find 
but you can also make it from scratch I have a

recipe for that but today I thought it would be 
a good chance for me to show you how you can do

a semi homemade version where you take red curry 
paste and then add things to it to turn it into

a muscle and paste because at the end of the day 
a muscleman paste is really your red curry paste

plus a few other spices so makes it a lot easier 
so what I've got here is just store-bought red

curry paste whatever favorite brand that you have 
and then these are my muscle man izing spices I've

got some toasted coriander seeds some cumin seeds 
some cardamom if you can find white cardamom that

would it be even better that's the cardamom that 
we use more often in Thailand but green will work

fine some cinnamon clove and nutmeg and because my 
red curry paste doesn't have any shrimp paste in

I'm just adding a little bit of fermented shrimp 
paste it's completely optional you don't have to

do it but I like to do it and then I'm just gonna 
pound it all together so all my whole spice is

in first grind that down into a powder there you 
go once it's nice and ground the cardamom shells

won't really cry and you can just pick that out 
so now these things go in and the red curry paste

goes in and there you go Mussa mun paste in just 
minutes so this step is completely optional I'm

gonna sear the beef get some nice browning on 
it because browning is flavor but if you want

to keep it simple and you just want to throw 
everything in the instant pot that's totally

fine as well you can actually sear things in the 
instant pot in the saute mode but it's smaller

than I have to do it in two batches so I just 
it's just easier for me to do in a separate pan

so while that's heating up let's talk beef I'm 
just using plain stew beef this is Chuck and

when choosing stew beef don't go with like the 
super lean one make sure the stew beef that you

have has some fat running through the meat because 
that's how you're going to prevent your your meat

from becoming really dry you know like it falls 
apart it's tender but it's really true dry and

stringy that's from the meat being very very lean 
so that's something to look out for so chuck is a

good good cut for that so some oil goes into the 
pan okay we just want a couple of spice to brown

and these things are helpful there you go nice 
and brown extra beefy flavor and I just do two

sides that's it let's get all this beef out and 
then to deglaze this I'm gonna just turn my heat

back on real quick and I'm just gonna add a tiny 
bit of water just enough to coat the pan so I can

just scrape up all this good stuff oh this is good 
grilled hamburger flavor and that is it's time to

get the instant pot going so I'm gonna start first 
as always by reducing my coconut milk so it's rich

and thick I'm gonna saute my curry paste in that 
so for that you want to use the sautee mode and

then ten minutes sure let's start with that and 
then I'm gonna do medium so the sautee mode just

basically turns this into a pot on the stove 
that's all it does which is convenient in many

many situations about half a cup of coconut milk 
so the coconut milk is boiling I'm not gonna wait

until it's reduced I'm just gonna add my curry 
paste right away because I have some time to

loosen it up in the coconut milk and then I'll 
let the coconut milk reduce with the paste the

pace is getting a little thicker I'm gonna turn it 
down to low just so I don't burn the paste so now

what you're starting to see is the oil the coconut 
oil separating from the pace the pace is basically

sizzling in the oil that's what you want to be at 
the rest of the coconut milk goes in so one very

important modification that I did for this recipe 
is I did not add any water because once we close

the lid on this thing it will not lose a single 
drop of water I don't need to add any at all and

I'll end up at the right amount of richness okay 
now the beef goes in try not to pour it in in one

go so it doesn't splash all over the place all of 
the juices well and don't forget the pan juice oh

yeah look at that beefy goodness it's like gravy 
okay so seasoning will now go in at this point

fish sauce nothing changes there and some it's 
just beeping telling me that my timer is up okay

okay okay let's you can off it for now - oh for 
God's sake just stop beeping and then what was

i plumb sugar going in so it doesn't need to be on 
at this point we're just getting ready to close it

now and some tamarind for a little bit of tartness 
and give that a nice stir make sure it's nice

close hello and I'm gonna go with pressure-cook 
mode time is gonna be thirty minutes sorry yes

thirty minutes so the timing I actually took from 
the instant pots guideline where for stew beef

they said 20 minutes for every pound of beef and 
I have pound and a half so I'm gonna do 30 minutes

pressure high delay no I don't want to delay keep 
warm on no I press Start and that is it now the 30

minutes doesn't actually start counting until 
it has come to temperature to temperature and

pressure so you see right now it says preheating 
so this depending on how much stuff you've got it

could take 10 minutes 15 minutes so just factor 
that into your planning as well that 30 minutes

is active cooking time for when the pressure has 
reached so this is what I meant in the beginning

when it says yeah it takes 30 minutes but 
really it's gonna take a total of about an hour

so the timer has gone off it is now done cooking 
now there are two ways to release the pressure

one is the terrifying one it's called the quick 
release you press this button and it just spews

out steam and pressure it's very aggressive and I 
don't like to do that the other way is what they

call the natural release method which basically 
means you let it cool down for a little bit first

before you release the steam or you just let it 
cool down until there's no more pressure built

up in there so for something thick and oily you 
actually should not use the quick release method

because it might actually spew out some oil or 
some of the actual food itself so I've never done

a quick release or muscleman I don't imagine it 
would be a good idea to do that because there's

quite a bit of fat in the coconut milk so I'm 
gonna let it naturally cool down for about 10

minutes but I also put a cold wet towel on top 
where the metal part of the lid is and this will

actually help it cool down even faster and I find 
that if I do this 10 minutes when I go to release

the pressure it's it's not aggressive alright 
so it's been just a little more than 10 minutes

this towel is now hot too by the way so just be 
careful when you take that off another sign that

you know that the pressure has left the inside 
is this little valve here will fall down so in

the beginning it goes up to seal the pot there's 
no more pressure inside it falls down and before I

open I always like to do a quick pressure release 
anyway just to make sure there's nothing sort of

built up inside and I press it nothing comes out 
okay so now we open sure smells like muscle man in

here okay so what you want to check at this point 
is that the beef is in fact tender so I'm gonna

pick one and I'm just gonna fork it whoa and it's 
tender I still need to add my potatoes and onions

and this is one of the I guess downfall of the 
pressure cookers you can't just throw everything

at once because I put my potatoes in with the beef 
by now it would be like mashed-potato must a month

which doesn't sound so bad so I'm gonna cook the 
potatoes just unnormal so I'm sought hey mo it's

just like stovetop and I did not peel them because 
if you scrap it well the potato peels ah hot are

edible and the most nutritious part of the whole 
potato so this is probably too much potato but

that's okay and my onions are also gonna go in 
also some roasted peanuts are gonna go in so now

it just needs to simmer for another 10-15 minutes 
depending on the size of your potato on saute mode

and could you pressure cook the potatoes as well 
yes of course but by the time it heats up it comes

to pressure and that's to cool down like you're 
not saving yourself any time so anything only

takes 10-15 minutes to cook regular it's just not 
worth going through all that trouble to pressure

cook it right so it just makes more sense this way 
all right and this is just the perfect consistency

for muscle munch so when you are working with 
a recipe that's not written for instant pod you

have to reduce the amount of liquid so I would 
just say add as much as you wanted out there to

be at the end because you're not gonna lose any 
during the cooking process so let's see how it

tastes shall we yes give me some of that potato 
of which I have so much it's curry and by the

way for our patreon members with access to the 
show after the show for this episode I'm gonna

tell you about my experience cooking other things

okay let's see look at that it falls apart super 
tender and it didn't take us three hours to do

yep definitely I would know that this was done 
in the pressure cooker like if somebody served

this to me it would be like here's a muscle 
on curry I wouldn't think twice about it so

it works really well as you can see there are 
a couple things to think through in terms of

methods and whatnot but the recipe that I have 
written up for this is to modify exactly for

the instant pots you can just use it as is 
but if you want to try other curry recipes

maybe use this sort of as a guideline for 
your methods but it tastes just as good and

that homemade curry paste again tastes just 
like a muscleman curry so you don't have to

make it completely from scratch if you don't 
want to I hope you enjoyed that the recipe as

always will be on hot eye-catching calm and when
